In Persian,lang-faبهائیIPA-fabæhɒːʔiːis pronounced with three syllables. The exact realization of the English pronunciation varies. TheOxford English DictionaryhasIPAc-enbæˈhɑːiːrespellbaHAHee,Merriam-WebsterhasIPAc-enbɑːˈhɑːiːrespellbahHAHee, and theRandom House DictionaryhasIPAc-enbəˈhɑːiːrespellbəHAHee, all with three syllables. SeecitationBahá’i Studyhttps://archive.org/details/ABahaiGlossaryAndPronunciationGuideAminBananiA Baha'i Glossary and Pronunciation GuideMP3andcitationhttp://bahai-library.com/wttp/programs.htmlDariusShahrokhWindows to the Past SeriesBahá’i Library  A Guide to Pronunciation part 1 and 2, for more pronunciation instructions.) is amonotheismmonotheisticreligion which emphasizes the spiritual unity of allhumankind.sfnDictionary2004Three core principles establish a basis for Bah' teachings and doctrine: theGod in the Bah' Faithunity of God, that there is only oneGodwho is the source of allcreation mythcreation; theBah' Faith and the unity of religionunity of religion, that all major religions have the same spiritual source and come from the same God; and theBah' Faith and the unity of humanityunity of humanity, that all humans have been created equal, coupled with theunity in diversity, that diversity of race and culture are seen as worthy of appreciation and acceptance.sfnHutter2005737–740According to the Bah' Faith's teachings, the human purpose is to learn to know and to love God through such methods asPrayer in the Bah' Faithprayer,Introspectionreflectionand being of service to humanity.

The Bah' Faith was founded byBah'u'llhin 19th-centuryPersia. Bah'u'llh was exiled for his teachings from Persia to theOttoman Empireand died while officially still a prisoner. After Bah'u'llh's death, under the leadership of his son,`Abdu'l-Bah, the religion spread from its Persian and Ottoman roots, and gained a footing in Europe and America, and was consolidated in Iran, where it suffers intensePersecution of Bah'spersecution.sfnAffolterJanuary 200575–114After the death of `Abdu'l-Bah, the leadership of the Bah' community entered a new phase, evolving from a single individual to an administrative order with both elected bodies and appointed individuals.sfnSmith200856There are probably more than 5 million Bah's around the world in more than 200 countries and territories.sfnHutter2005737–40SeeBah' statistics#Worldwide figuresBah' statisticsfor a breakdown of different estimates.

In the Bah' Faith, religious history is seen to have unfolded through a series of divine messengers, each of whom established a religion that was suited to the needs of the time and to the capacity of the people. These messengers have includedAbrahamicfiguresMoses,Jesus,Muhammad, as well asIndian religionsIndianonesKrishna,Buddha, and others. For Bah's, the most recent messengers are theBbandBah'u'llh. In Bah' belief, each consecutive messenger prophesied of messengers to follow, and Bah'u'llh's life and teachings fulfilled theeschatologyend-timepromises of previous scriptures. Humanity is understood to be in a process of collective evolution, and the need of the present time is for the gradual establishment of peace, justice and unity on a global scale.sfnSmith2008107–9
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: The wordBah'is used either as an adjective to refer to the Bah' Faith or as a term for a follower of Bah'u'llh. The word is not a noun meaning the religion as a whole.sfnStockman2006It is derived from the ArabicGreatest NameBah'(langarبهاء), meaning "glory" or "splendor".Bah's prefer the orthographiesBah',Bah's,the Bb,Bah'u'llh, and`Abdu'l-Bah, using aBah' orthographyparticular transcriptionof theArabic languageArabicandPersian languagePersianin publications. "Bahai", "Bahais", "Baha'i", "the Bab", "Bahaullah" and "Baha'u'llah" are often used when diacriticals are unavailable.The term "Bahaism" (or "Baha'ism") is still used, mainly in a pejorative sense.sfnHatcherMartin1998xiiisfnCentre for Faith and the Media
article.heading: Beliefs
article.paragraph: Three core principles establish a basis for Bah' teachings and doctrine: theGod in the Bah' Faithunity of God, theBah' Faith and the unity of religionunity of religion, and theBah' Faith and the unity of humanityunity of humanity.sfnHutter2005737–740From these postulates stems the belief that God periodically reveals his will through divine messengers, whose purpose is to transform the character of humankind and to develop, within those who respond, moral and spiritual qualities. Religion is thus seen as orderly, unified, and progressive from age to age.sfnSmith2008108–109
article.heading: God
article.paragraph: MainGod in the Bahá'í FaithFile:Bahaitemplesydney.JPGthumbuprightalt=A white domed buildingBah' Temple,Ingleside, New South WalesIngleside, Sydney, AustraliaThe Bah' writings describe a single, personal, inaccessible, omniscient, omnipresent, imperishable, and almighty God who is the creator of all things in the universe.sfnSmith2008106Theexistence of Godand theuniverseis thought to be eternal, without a beginning or end.sfnDaumeWatson1992Though inaccessible directly, God is nevertheless seen as conscious of creation, with a will and purpose that is expressed through messengers termedManifestations of God.sfnSmith2008106–107sfnSmith2008111–112

Bah' teachings state that God is too great for humans to fully comprehend, or to create a complete and accurate image of, by themselves. Therefore, human understanding of God is achieved through his revelations via his Manifestations.sfnHatcher20051–38sfnCole19821–38In the Bah' religion, God is often referred to by titles and attributes (for example, the All-Powerful, or the All-Loving), and there is a substantial emphasis onmonotheism; such doctrines as theTrinityare seen as compromising, if not contradicting, the Bah' view that God is single and has no equal.sfnStockman1992The Bah' teachings state that the attributes which are applied to God are used to translate Godliness into human terms and also to help individuals concentrate on their own attributes in worshipping God to develop their potentialities on their spiritual path.sfnHatcher20051-38sfnCole19821-38According to the Bah' teachings the human purpose is to learn to know and love God through such methods asPrayer in the Bah' Faithprayer,Introspectionreflection, and being of service to others.sfnHatcher20051-38File:Wilmette how side.jpguprightalt=A white column with ornate designs carved into it, including a Star of DavidleftthumbSymbols of many religions on a pillar of theBah' House of Worship (Wilmette, Illinois)Bah' House of Worshipin Wilmette, Illinois, U.S.
article.heading: Religion
article.paragraph: MainBahá'í Faith and the unity of religionSee alsoProgressive revelation (Bahá'í)Bah' notions of progressive religious revelation result in their accepting the validity of the well known religions of the world, whose founders and central figures are seen as Manifestations of God. Religious history is interpreted as a series ofdispensationalismdispensations, where eachmanifestationbrings a somewhat broader and more advancedrevelationthat is rendered as a text of scripture and passed on through history with greater or lesser reliability but at least true in substance,cite bookRobert H. StockmanThe Baha'i Faith: A Guide For The Perplexedhttps://books.google.com/books?id21 November 2012Bloomsbury Publishing978-1-4411-0447-240–42suited for the time and place in which it was expressed.sfnDaumeWatson1992Specific religious social teachings (for example, the direction of prayer, or dietary restrictions) may be revoked by a subsequent manifestation so that a more appropriate requirement for the time and place may be established. Conversely, certain general principles (for example, neighbourliness, or charity) are seen to be universal and consistent. In Bah' belief, this process of progressive revelation will not end; however, it is believed to be cyclical. Bah's do not expect a new manifestation of God to appear within 1000 years of Bah'u'llh's revelation.sfnMcMullen20007

Bah' beliefs are sometimes described asSyncretismsyncreticcombinations of earlier religious beliefs.sfnStockman1997Bah's, however, assert that their religion is a distinct tradition with its ownBah' literaturescriptures,Bah' teachingsteachings,Bah' lawslaws, andBah' historyhistory.sfnDaumeWatson1992sfnBausani2012While the religion was initially seen as a sect of Islam, most religious specialists now see it as an independent religion, with its religious background inShi'a Islambeing seen as analogous to the Jewish context in which Christianity was established.sfnVan der Vyer1996449Muslim institutions and clergy, bothSunni IslamSunniandShia IslamShia, consider Bah's to be deserters orApostasy in Islamapostates from Islam, which has led to Bah's beingPersecution of Bah'spersecuted.sfnBoyleSheen1997119-120sfnAfshari2001119-120Bah's describe their faith as an independent world religion, differing from the other traditions in its relative age and in the appropriateness of Bah'u'llh's teachings to the modern context.sfnLundberg2005Bah'u'llh is believed to have fulfilled theEschatologymessianic expectationsof these precursor faiths.sfbBuck2004143-178
article.heading: Human beings
article.paragraph: File:Ringstone.svgalt=A stylized Arabic figure which has intersecting lines that lock around rings and five-pointed stars to either sidethumbrightTheBah' symbols#Ringstone symbolRingstone symbolrepresents humanity's connection to GodSee alsoBahá'í Faith and the unity of humanityBahá'í Faith on life after deathThe Bah' writings state that human beings have a "rationalSoul (spirit)soul", and that this provides the species with a unique capacity to recognize God's station and humanity's relationship with its creator. Every human is seen to have a duty to recognize God through HisManifestation of Godmessengers, and to conform to their teachings.sfnMcMullen200057-58Through recognition and obedience, service to humanity and regular prayer and spiritual practice, the Bah' writings state that the soul becomes closer to God, the spiritual ideal in Bah' belief. When a human dies, the soul passes into the next world, where its spiritual development in the physical world becomes a basis for judgment and advancement in the spiritual world. Heaven and Hell are taught to be spiritual states of nearness or distance from God that describe relationships in this world and the next, and not physical places of reward and punishment achieved after death.sfnMasumian1995

The Bah' writings emphasize the essential equality of human beings, and the abolition of prejudice. Humanity is seen as essentially one, though highly varied; its diversity of race and culture are seen as worthy of appreciation and acceptance. Doctrines of racism, nationalism, caste, social class, and gender-based hierarchy are seen as artificial impediments to unity.sfnHutter2005737–740The Bah' teachings state that the unification of humanity is the paramount issue in the religious and political conditions of the present world.sfnDaumeWatson1992
article.heading: Teachings
Summary
article.paragraph: Shoghi Effendi, the appointed head of the religion from 1921 to 1957, wrote the following summary of what he considered to be the distinguishing principles ofBah'u'llh's teachings, which, he said, together with the laws and ordinances of theKitb-i-Aqdasconstitute the bedrock of the Bah' Faith:

arg.name: The independent search after truth, unfettered by [[superstition]] or tradition; the oneness of the entire [[Human|human race]], the pivotal principle and fundamental doctrine of the Faith; the basic unity of all religions; the condemnation of all forms of [[prejudice]], whether religious, racial, class or national; the harmony which must exist between religion and science; the equality of men and women, the two wings on which the bird of human kind is able to soar; the introduction of compulsory education; the adoption of a [[Bahá'í Faith and auxiliary language|universal auxiliary language]]; the abolition of the extremes of wealth and poverty; the institution of a [[World government|world tribunal]] for the adjudication of disputes between nations; the exaltation of work, performed in the spirit of service, to the rank of [[worship]]; the glorification of justice as the ruling principle in human society, and of religion as a bulwark for the protection of all peoples and nations; and the establishment of a permanent and [[World peace|universal peace]] as the supreme goal of all mankind—these stand out as the essential elements [which Bahá'u'lláh proclaimed].{{sfn|Effendi|1944|pp

article.heading: Mystical teachings
article.paragraph: Although theBah' teachingshave a strong emphasis on social and ethical issues, there exist a number of foundational texts that have been described as mystical.sfnDaumeWatson1992TheSeven Valleysis considered Bah'u'llh's "greatest mystical composition." It was written to a follower ofSufism, in the style ofAttar Neyshapurinbsp`Attar, ThePersian peoplePersianMuslim poet,sfnSmith2000311: {{nowrap|"Seven Valleys"}}and sets forth the stages of the soul's journey towards God. It was first translated into English in 1906, becoming one of the earliest available books of Bah'u'llh to the West. TheHidden Wordsis another book written by Bah'u'llh during the same period, containing 153 short passages in which Bah'u'llh claims to have taken the basic essence of certain spiritual truths and written them in brief form.sfnSmith2000181: {{nowrap|"Hidden Words"}}
article.heading: Covenant
article.paragraph: MainCovenant of Bahá'u'lláhThe Bah' teachings speak of both a "Greater Covenant",sfnTaherzadeh1972being universal and endless, and a "Lesser Covenant", being unique to each religious dispensation. The Lesser Covenant is viewed as an agreement between a Messenger of God and his followers and includes social practices and the continuation of authority in the religion. At this time Bah's view Bah'u'llh's revelation as a binding lesser covenant for his followers; in the Bah' writings being firm in the covenant is considered a virtue to work toward.sfnMomen1995: {{nowrap|"Lower covenant"}}The Greater Covenant is viewed as a more enduring agreement between God and humanity, where a Manifestation of God is expected to come to humanity about every thousand years, at times of turmoil and uncertainty.With unity as an essential teaching of the religion, Bah's follow anBah' administrationadministrationthey believe is divinely ordained, and therefore see attempts to create schisms and divisions as efforts that are contrary to the teachings of Bah'u'llh. Schisms have occurred over the succession of authority, but anyBah' divisionshave had relatively little success and have failed to attract a sizeable following.sfnMacEoin1989448The followers of such divisions are regarded asCovenant-breakersand shunned, essentiallyExcommunicationexcommunicated.sfnMomen1995: {{nowrap|"Lower covenant"}}sfnSmith2008173
article.heading: Canonical texts
article.paragraph: MainBahá'í literatureThecanonical textsare the writings of theBb,Bah'u'llh,`Abdu'l-Bah, Shoghi Effendi and theUniversal House of Justice, and the authenticated talks of `Abdu'l-Bah. The writings of the Bb and Bah'u'llh are considered as divine revelation, the writings and talks of `Abdu'l-Bah and the writings of Shoghi Effendi as authoritative interpretation, and those of the Universal House of Justice as authoritative legislation and elucidation. Some measure of divine guidance is assumed for all of these texts.sfnSmith2000100-101: {{nowrap|"Canonical texts"}}Some of Bah'u'llh's most important writings include theKitb-i-Aqdas, literally theMost Holy Book, which is his book of laws,sfnHatcherMartin199846theKitb-i-qn, literally theBook of Certitude, which became the foundation of much of Bah' belief,sfnHatcherMartin1998137theGems of Divine Mysteries, which includes further doctrinal foundations, and theSeven Valleysandthe Four Valleyswhich are mystical treatises.sfnSmith200820

article.paragraph: Bah' history follows a sequence of leaders, beginning with theBb's declaration inShiraz, Iranon the evening of 22 May 1844, and ultimately resting on an administrative order established by the central figures of the religion. The Bah' community was mostly confined to theQajar dynastyPersianandOttoman EmpireOttomanempires until after the death of Bah'u'llh in 1892, at which time he had followers in 13 countries of Asia and Africa.sfnTaherzadeh1987125Under the leadership of his son, `Abdu'l-Bah, the religion gained a footing in Europe and America, and was consolidated in Iran, where it still suffers intensePersecution of Bah'spersecution.sfnAffolterJanuary 200575–114After the death of `Abdu'l-Bah in 1921, the leadership of the Bah' community entered a new phase, evolving from a single individual to an administrative order with both elected bodies and appointed individuals.sfnSmith200856
article.heading: The Bb
article.paragraph: MainBábFile:Shrine Bab North West.jpgleftalt=A domed buildingthumbuprightShrine of the Bbin Haifa, IsraelOn the evening of 22 May 1844, Siyyid `Al-Muhammad of Shiraz, Iran proclaimed that he was "the Bb" (langarالباب"the Gate"), referring to his later claim to the station ofMahdi, the Twelfth Imam ofShi'a IslamShi`a Islam.sfnAffolterJanuary 200575–114His followers were therefore known asBbismBbs. As the Bb's teachings spread, which the Islamic clergy saw as a threat, his followers came under increased persecution and torture.sfnDaumeWatson1992The conflicts escalated in several places to military sieges by theList of kings of PersiaShah's army. The Bb himself was imprisoned and eventually executed in 1850.sfnWinter1997

Bah's see the Bb as the forerunner of the Bah' Faith, because the Bb's writings introduced the concept of "He whom God shall make manifest", a Messianic figure whose coming, according to Bah's, was announced in the scriptures of all of the world's great religions, and whom Bah'u'llh, the founder of the Bah' Faith, claimed to be in 1863.sfnDaumeWatson1992Shrine of the BbThe Bb's tomb, located inHaifaHaifa, Israel, is an important place ofBah' pilgrimagepilgrimagefor Bah's. The remains of the Bb were brought secretly fromIranto the Holy Land and eventually interred in the tomb built for them in a spot specifically designated by Bah'u'llh.sfnBalyuzi2001The main written works translated into English of the Bb's are collected inSelections from the Writings of the Bbout of the estimated 135 works.sfnUniversal House of JusticeSeptember 2002349-350
article.heading: Bah'u'llh
article.paragraph: MainBahá'u'lláhMrz Husayn `Al Nr was one of the early followers of the Bb, and later took the title of Bah'u'llh. He was arrested and imprisoned for this involvement in 1852. Bah'u'llh relates that in 1853, while incarcerated in the dungeon of theSyh-ChlinTehran, he received the first intimations that he was the one anticipated by the Bb.sfnHutter2005737–740

Shortly thereafter he was expelled fromTehrantoBaghdad, in theOttoman Empire;sfnHutter2005737–740then to Constantinople (nowIstanbul); and then to Adrianople (nowEdirne). In 1863, at the time of his banishment from Baghdad to Constantinople, Bah'u'llh declared his claim to a divine mission to his family and followers. Tensions then grew between him andSubh-i-Azal, the appointed leader of the Bbs who did not recognize Bah'u'llh's claim. Throughout the rest of his life Bah'u'llh gained the allegiance of most of the Bbs, who came to be known as Bah's. Beginning in 1866, he began declaring his mission as a Messenger of God in letters to the world's religious and secular rulers, includingPope Pius IX,Napoleon III, andQueen Victoria.

In 1868 Bah'u'llh was banished by SultanAbdlziza final time to the Ottoman penal colony ofAcre, Israel`Akk, in present-dayIsrael. Towards the end of his life, the strict and harsh confinement was gradually relaxed, and he was allowed to live in a home near `Akk, while still officially a prisoner of that city.sfnCole1989422-429: [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/baha-allah {{nowrap|"BAHĀʾ-ALLĀH"}} ]He died there in 1892. Bah's regard his resting place atMansion of BahjBahjas theQiblihto which they turn in prayer each day.sfnSmith200820–21, 28

Bah'u'llh wroteList of writings of Bah'u'llhmany written workstaken as scripture in the religion of which only a fraction have been translated into English.sfnSmith200079-80There have been 15,000 works both small and large notedsfnUniversal House of JusticeSeptember 2002349-350- the most significant of which are theKitb-i-AqdasMost Holy Book, theKitb-i-qnBook of Certitude, theHidden Words, and theSeven Valleys. There is also a series of compilation volumes of smaller works the most significant of which is theGleanings from the Writings of Bah'u'llh.
article.heading: `Abdu'l-Bah
article.paragraph: File:Abdul-Bah portrait.jpgthumb`Abdu'l-BahMain`Abdu'l-Bahá`Abbs Effendi was Bah'u'llh's eldest son, known by the title of `Abdu'l-Bah (Servant of Bah). His father left aTablets of Bah'u'llh#Kitb-i-`Ahd (Book of the Covenant)Willthat appointed `Abdu'l-Bah as the leader of the Bah' community, and designated him as the "Centre of the Covenant", "Head of the Faith", and the sole authoritative interpreter of Bah'u'llh's writings.sfnBalyuzi2001sfnSmith200847`Abdu'l-Bah had shared his father's long exile and imprisonment, which continued until `Abdu'l-Bah's own release as a result of theYoung Turk Revolutionin 1908. Following his release he led a life of travelling, speaking, teaching, and maintaining correspondence with communities of believers and individuals, expounding the principles of the Bah' Faith.sfnHutter2005737–740

It is estimated that `Abdu'l-Bah wrote over 27,000 works mostly in the form of letters of which only a fraction have been translated into English.sfnUniversal House of JusticeSeptember 2002349-350Among the more well known areThe Secret of Divine Civilization, theTablet to Dr. ForelTablet to Auguste-Henri Forel, andSome Answered Questions. Additionally notes taken of a number of his talks were published in various volumes likeParis Talksduring his`Abdu'l-Bah's journeys to the Westjourneys to the West.
article.heading: Bah' administration
article.paragraph: MainBahá'í administrationBah'u'llh'sKitb-i-AqdasandTheWill and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahare foundational documents of the Bah' administrative order. Bah'u'llh established the electedUniversal House of Justice, and `Abdu'l-Bah established the appointed hereditary Guardianship and clarified the relationship between the two institutions.sfnBalyuzi2001sfnSmith200855–57In his Will, `Abdu'l-Bah appointed his eldest grandson, Shoghi Effendi, as the firstGuardianof the Bah' Faith, serving as head of the religion until his death, for 36 years.sfnSmith200855

Shoghi Effendi throughout his lifetime translatedBah' texts; developed global plans for the expansion of the Bah' community; developed theBah' World Centre; carried on a voluminous correspondence with communities and individuals around the world; and built the administrative structure of the religion, preparing the community for the election of the Universal House of Justice.sfnHutter2005737–740He died in 1957 under conditions that did not allow for a successor to be appointed.sfnTaherzadeh2000347-363sfnSmith200858–69

At local, regional, and national levels, Bah's elect members to nine-personSpiritual AssemblySpiritual Assemblies, which run the affairs of the religion. There are alsoInstitution of the Counsellorsappointed individualsworking at various levels, including locally and internationally, which perform the function of propagating the teachings and protecting the community. The latter do not serve as clergy, which the Bah' Faith does not have.sfnDaumeWatson1992sfnSmith2008160The Universal House of Justice, first elected in 1963, remains the successor and supreme governing body of the Bah' Faith, and its 9 members are elected every five years by the members of all National Spiritual Assemblies.sfnStockman1995Any male Bah', 21 years or older, is eligible to be elected to the Universal House of Justice; all other positions are open to male and female Bah's.sfnSmith2008205
article.heading: International plans
article.paragraph: File:Willmette how.jpgthumbalt=A white domed building with a large garden leading toward itBah' House of Worship (Wilmette, Illinois)Bah' House of Worship,Wilmette, IllinoisIn 1937, Shoghi Effendi launched a seven-year plan for the Bah's of North America, followed by another in 1946.sfnDaneshDaneshDanesh1991In 1953, he launched the first international plan, theTen Year CrusadeTen Year World Crusade. This plan included extremely ambitious goals for the expansion of Bah' communities and institutions, the translation ofBah' textsinto several new languages, and the sending ofPioneering (Bah')Bah' pioneersinto previously unreached nations.sfnHassal19961-21He announced in letters during the Ten Year Crusade that it would be followed by other plans under the direction of the Universal House of Justice, which was elected in 1963 at the culmination of the Crusade. The House of Justice then launched a nine-year plan in 1964, and a series of subsequent multi-year plans of varying length and goals followed, guiding the direction of the international Bah' community.sfnSmithMomen198963-91

Annually, on 21 April, the Universal House of Justice sends aRidvnmessage to the worldwide Bah community,sfnSmith2000297: "Ridván"which generally gives an update on the progress made concerning the current plan, and provides further guidance for the year to come.All Ridvn messages can be found atBah' Library Online.The Bah's around the world are currently being encouraged to focus on capacity building through children's classes, youth groups, devotional gatherings, and a systematic study of the religion known asBah' study circlestudy circles.sfnGervais2008sfnUniversal House of Justice17 January 2003Further focuses are involvement in social action and participation in the prevalent discourses of society.sfnVahedi2 March 2011sfnUniversal House of Justice21 April 2010The years from 2001 until 2021 represent four successive five-year plans, culminating in the centennial anniversary of the passing of`Abdu'l-Bah.sfnUniversal House Of Justice2006
article.heading: Demographics
article.paragraph: MainBahá'í Faith by countrySee alsoBahá'í statisticsFile:New delhi temple.jpgthumbalt=A large temple in the shape of an open lotus flowerupright=1.25TheLotus Temple, aBah' House of Worshipin New Delhi,India. It attracts an average of 4 million visitors a year.A Bah' published document reported 4.74 million Bah's in 1986 growing at a rate of 4.4%.sfnRabbaniJuly 19872-7Bah' sources since 1991 usually estimate the worldwide Bah' population to be above 5 million.sfnBahá'í World News Service2010TheWorld Christian Encyclopediaestimated 7.1 million Bah's in the world in 2000, representing 218 countries,sfnBarrett20014and 7.3 million in 2010sfnAssociation of Religion Data Archives2010with the same source. They further state: "The Baha'i Faith is the only religion to have grown faster in every United Nations region over the past 100 years than the general population; Bahai was thus the fastest-growing religion between 1910 and 2010, growing at least twice as fast as the population of almost every UN region."sfnJohnsonGrim201359-62This source's only systematic flaw was to consistently have a higher estimate of Christians than other cross-national data sets.sfnHsuReynoldsHackettGibbon2008691–692

From its origins in theQajar dynastyPersianandOttoman EmpireOttomanEmpires, by the early 20th century there were a number of converts inSouth AsiaSouthandSouth East Asia, Europe, and North America. During the 1950s and 1960s, vastPioneering (Bah')travel teachingefforts brought the religion to almost every country and territory of the world. By the 1990s, Bah's were developing programs for systematic consolidation on a large scale, and the early 21st century saw large influxes of new adherents around the world. The Bah' Faith is currently the largest religious minority in Iran,sfnInternational Federation of Human RightsAugust 2003Panama,sfnAssociation of Religion Data Archives2010[http://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_174_2.asp National Profile: Panama]and Belize;sfnAssociation of Religion Data Archives2010[http://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_23_2.asp National Profile: Belize]the second largest international religion in Bolivia,sfnAssociation of Religion Data Archives2010[http://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_27_2.asp National Profile: Bolivia]Zambia,sfnAssociation of Religion Data Archives2010[http://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_245_2.asp National Profile: Zambia]and Papua New Guinea;sfnAssociation of Religion Data Archives2010[http://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_175_2.asp National Profile: Papua New Guinea]and the third largest international religion in ChadsfnReligious Intelligence: {{nowrap|Country Profile: Chad}}sfnAssociation of Religion Data Archives2010[http://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_45_2.asp National Profile: Chad]and Kenya.sfnAssociation of Religion Data Archives2010[http://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_121_2.asp National Profiles: Kenya]
According toWorld AlmanacThe World Almanac and Book of Facts 2004:

template.arg: The majority of Bahá'ís live in Asia (3.6 million), Africa (1.8 million), and Latin America (900,000). According to some estimates, the largest Bahá'í community in the world is in [[India]], with 2.2 million Bahá'ís, next is [[Iran]], with 350,000, the US, with 150,000, and Brazil, with 60,000. Aside from these countries, numbers vary greatly. Currently, no country has a Bahá'í majority.{{sfn|Park|2004}}

article.paragraph: The Bah' religion was listed inThe Britannica Book of the Year(1992present) as the second most widespread of the world's independent religions in terms of the number of countries represented. According toBritannica, the Bah' Faith (as of 2002) is established in 247 countries and territories; represents over 2,100 ethnic, racial, and tribal groups; has scriptures translated into over 800 languages; and has an estimated seven million adherents worldwide.sfnEncyclopædia Britannica2002Additionally, Bah's haveBah' administrationself-organizedin most of the nations of the world.
The Bah' religion was ranked by the Foreign Policy magazine as the world's secondfastest growing religionby percentage (1.7%) in 2007.sfnForeign Policy Magazine1 May 2007
article.heading: Social practices
Laws
article.paragraph: MainBahá'í lawsFile:Bah' gardens by David Shankbone.jpgalt=Elaborate gardens with several gates and a walkway leading to a domed building in the distancethumbBah' gardensinHaifa, Israel.The laws of the Bah' Faith primarily come from theKitb-i-Aqdas, written by Bah'u'llh.sfnSmith2000223-225: "Law"The following are a few examples of basic laws and religious observances.

list.listitem: Prayer in the Bah' Faithconsists of obligatory prayer and devotional (general) prayer. Bah's over the age of 15 must individually recite anObligatory Bah' prayersobligatory prayereach day, using fixed words and form. In addition to the daily obligatory prayer, believers are directed to daily offerPrayer in the Bah' Faithdevotional prayerand to meditate and study sacred scripture. There is no set form for devotions and meditations, though the devotional prayers written by the central figures of the Bah' Faith and collected in prayer books are held in high esteem. Reading aloud of prayers from prayer books is a typical feature of Bah' gatherings.
Backbitingand gossip are prohibited and denounced.
Adult Bah's in good health should observe aNineteen Day Fastnineteen-day sunrise-to-sunset fasteach year from 2 March through 20 March.
Bah's are forbidden to drinkalcoholic beveragealcoholor to take drugs, unless prescribed by doctors.
Sexual intercourseis only permitted between a husband and wife, and thuspremarital,extramarital sexextramarital, and homosexual intercourse are forbidden.(See alsoHomosexuality and the Bah' Faith)
Gambling is forbidden.
Fanaticismis forbidden.
Adherence toritualis discouraged, with the notable exception of the obligatory prayers.
Abstaining fromPartisan (political)partisanpolitics is required.

article.paragraph: While some of the laws from the Kitb-i-Aqdas are applicable at the present time and may be enforced to a degree by the administrative institutions,sfnSmith2008158–161Bah'u'llh has provided for the progressive application of other laws that are dependent upon the existence of a predominantly Bah' society. The laws, when not in direct conflict with the civil laws of the country of residence, are binding on every Bah',sfnSmith2008158and the observance of personal laws, such asPrayer in the Bah' Faithprayeror fasting, is the sole responsibility of the individual.sfnSmith2000223-225: "Law"sfnWalbridge1996
article.heading: Marriage
article.paragraph: MainBahá'í marriageThe purpose of marriage in the Bah'i faith is mainly to foster spiritual harmony, fellowship and unity between a man and a woman and to provide a stable and loving environment for the rearing of children.sfnSmith2008164–165The Bah' teachings on marriage call it afortress for well-being and salvationand place marriage and the family as the foundation of the structure ofsocietyhuman society.sfnSmith2008164Bah'u'llh highly praised marriage, discouraged divorce and homosexuality, and requiredchastityoutside of marriage; Bah'u'llh taught that a husband and wife should strive to improve the spiritual life of each other.sfnBaha'is of Warwick12 October 2003Interracial marriageis also highly praised throughout Bah' scripture.sfnSmith2008164

Bah's intending to marry are asked to obtain a thorough understanding of the other's character before deciding to marry.sfnSmith2008164Although parents should notArranged marriagechoose partners for their children, once two individuals decide to marry, they must receive the consent of all living biological parents, whether they are Bah' or not. The Bah' marriage ceremony is simple; the only compulsory part of the wedding is the reading of the wedding vows prescribed byBah'u'llhwhich both the groom and the bride read, in the presence of two witnesses.sfnSmith2008164The vows are "We will all, verily, abide by the Will of God."sfnSmith2008164
article.heading: Work
article.paragraph: Monasticismis forbidden, and Bah's attempt to ground their spirituality in ordinary daily life. Performing useful work, for example, is not only required but considered a form of worship.sfnDaumeWatson1992Bah'u'llh prohibited aMendicancymendicantandAsceticismasceticlifestyle.sfnSmith2008154–155The importance of self-exertion and service to humanity in one's spiritual life is emphasised further in Bah'u'llh's writings, where he states that work done in the spirit of service to humanity enjoys a rank equal to that of prayer and worship in the sight of God.sfnDaumeWatson1992
article.heading: Places of worship
article.paragraph: MainBahá'í House of WorshipFile:House of Worship Germany 2007.jpgthumbalt=A white domed building with palm trees in front of itBah' House of Worship,Langenhain, GermanyMost Bah' meetings occur in individuals' homes, local Bah' centers, or rented facilities. Worldwide, there are currently seven Bah' Houses of Worship, with an eighth under construction in Chile,sfnAdherents18 October 2001and a further seven planned as of April 2012.sfnBahá'í World News Service22 April 2012Bah' writings refer to an institution called a "Mashriqu'l-Adhkr" (Dawning-place of the Mention of God), which is to form the center of a complex of institutions including a hospital, university, and so on.sfnSmith2008194The first ever Mashriqu'l-Adhkr inAshgabat`Ishqbd, Turkmenistan, has been the most complete House of Worship.sfnSmith2000236: {{nowrap|"Mashriqu'l-Adkhar"}}
article.heading: Calendar
article.paragraph: MainBahá'í calendarThe Bah' calendar is based upon the calendar established by the Bb. The year consists of 19 months, each having 19 days, with four or fiveAyym-i-Hintercalary days, to make a fullTropical yearsolar year.sfnHutter2005737–740The Bah' New Year corresponds to the traditionalPersian peoplePersianNew Year, calledBah' Naw-RzNaw Rz, and occurs on thevernal equinox, 21 March, at the end of the month of fasting. Bah' communities gather at the beginning of each month at a meeting called aNineteen Day FeastFeastfor worship, consultation and socializing.sfnDaumeWatson1992

Each of the 19 months is given a name which is an attribute of God; some examples include Bah (Splendour), Ilm (Knowledge), and Jaml (Beauty).sfnSmith2008188–190The Bah' week is familiar in that it consists of seven days, with each day of the week also named after an attribute of God. Bah's observe 11Ascension of Bah'u'llhHoly Daysthroughout the year, with work suspended on 9 of these. These days commemorate important anniversaries in the history of the religion.sfnSmith2008188
article.heading: Symbols
article.paragraph: File:051907 Wilmette IMG 1404 The Greatest Name.jpgalt=Arabic script inscribed on a metal platethumbupright=1.25The calligraphy of theBah' symbols#The Greatest NameGreatest NameMainBahá'í symbolsThe symbols of the religion are derived from the Arabic word Bah (langarبهاء"splendor" or "glory"), with aAbjad numeralsnumerical valueof 9, which is why the most common symbol is thenine-pointed star.sfnSmith2000167-168: {{nowrap|"Greatest Name"}}The ringstone symbol and calligraphy of the Greatest Name are also often encountered. The former consists of two five-pointed stars interspersed with a stylized Bah whose shape is meant to recall the three onenesses,sfnFaizi1968while the latter is a calligraphic rendering of the phrase Y Bah'u'l-Abh (langarيا بهاء الأبهى"O Glory of the Most Glorious!").clear leftThe five-pointed star is the symbol of the Bah' Faith.sfnEffendi197351-52sfnBahai-library.comNine-Pointed StarIn the Bah' Faith, the star is known as theHaykal(lang-ar"temple"), and it was initiated and established by theBb. The Bb andBah'u'llhwrote various works in the form of apentagram.sfnAbout.comHaykal
article.heading: Socio-economic development

link.part: alt=A black-and-white photograph of several dozen girls seated in front of a school building

Students of ''School for Girls'',Tehran, 13 August 1933. This photograph may be of the students of ''Tarbiyat School for Girls'' which was established by the Bah' Community of Tehran in 1911; the school was closed by government decree in 1934.sfnBahá'í International Community2005

article.paragraph: Since its inception the Bah' Faith has had involvement insocio-economic developmentbeginning by giving greater freedom to women,sfnMomen1994: Section 9: Social and economic developmentpromulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,sfnKingdon1997and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics.sfnMomen1994: Section 9: Social and economic development

The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the Universal House of Justice dated 20 October 1983 was released. Bah's were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the Bah' teachings, in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. Worldwide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bah' socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482.sfnSmithMomen198963-91
article.heading: United Nations
article.paragraph: Bah'u'llh wrote of the need forworld governmentin this age of humanity's collective life. Because of this emphasis the international Bah' community has chosen to support efforts of improvinginternational relationsthrough organizations such as theLeague of Nationsand theUnited Nations, with some reservations about the present structure and constitution of the UN.sfnMomen2007TheBah' International Communityis an agency under the direction of the Universal House of Justice in Haifa, and has consultative status with the following organizations:sfnMcMullen200039sfnBahá'í International Community6 June 2000

list.listitem: United Nations Children's Fund(UNICEF)
UNIFEMUnited Nations Development Fund for Women(UNIFEM)
United Nations Economic and Social Council(ECOSOC)
United Nations Environment Programme(UNEP)
World Health Organization(WHO)

article.paragraph: The Bah' International Community has offices at the United Nations in New York andGenevaand representations to United Nations regional commissions and other offices inAddis Ababa,Bangkok,Nairobi, Rome,Santiago, ChileSantiago, andVienna.sfnBahá'í International Community6 June 2000In recent years an Office of the Environment and an Office for the Advancement of Women were established as part of its United Nations Office. The Bah' Faith has also undertaken joint development programs with various other United Nations agencies. In the 2000Millennium Development GoalsMillennium Forumof the United Nations a Bah' was invited as the only non-governmental speaker during the summit.sfnBahá'í World News Service8 September 2000
article.heading: Persecution

link.part: alt=Broken cinder blocks and felled palm trees
The Bah' cemetery inYazdafter its desecration by the government

article.paragraph: Bah's continue to be persecuted in Islamic countries, as Islamic leaders do not recognize the Bah' Faith as an independent religion, but rather asapostasy from Islam. The most severe persecutions have occurred inBah' Faith in IranIran, where over 200 Bah's were executed between 1978 and 1998,sfnInternational Federation of Human RightsAugust 2003and inBah' Faith in EgyptEgypt. The rights of Bah's have been restricted to greater or lesser extents in numerous other countries, includingBah' Faith in AfghanistanAfghanistan,sfnInternational Religious Freedom Report2013[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/religiousfreedom/index.htm?yearIndonesia,sfnInternational Religious Freedom Report2013[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/religiousfreedom/index.htm?yearIraq,sfnInternational Religious Freedom Report2013[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/religiousfreedom/index.htm?yearMorocco,sfnInternational Religious Freedom Report2013[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/religiousfreedom/index.htm?yearsfnCommittee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination1994: see paragraphs 215 and 220and several countries insub-Saharan Africa.sfnSmithMomen198963-91
article.heading: Iran
article.paragraph: The marginalization of the Iranian Bah's by current governments is rooted in historical efforts by Muslim clergy to persecute the religious minority. When the Bb started attracting a large following, the clergy hoped to stop the movement from spreading by stating that its followers were enemies of God. These clerical directives led to mob attacks and public executions.sfnAffolterJanuary 200575–114Starting in the twentieth century, in addition to repression that impacted individual Bah's, centrally directed campaigns that targeted the entire Bah' community and its institutions were initiated.sfnIran Human Rights Documentation Center2007In one case inYazdin 1903 more than 100 Bah's were killed.sfnNash1982Bah' schools, such as the Tarbiyat boys' and girls' schools in Tehran, were closed in the 1930s and 40s, Bah' marriages were not recognized andBah' textswere censored.sfnIran Human Rights Documentation Center2007sfnSanasarian200052-53

During the reign ofMohammad Reza Pahlavi, to divert attention from economic difficulties in Iran and from a growing nationalist movement, a campaign of persecution against the Bah's was instituted.In line with this is the thinking that the government encouraged the campaign to distract attention from more serious problems, including acute economic difficulties. Beyond this lay the difficulty which the regime faced in harnessing the nationalist movement that had supported Musaddiq.harvAkhavi198076–78An approved and coordinated anti-Bah' campaign (to incite public passion against the Bah's) started in 1955 and it included the spreading of anti-Bah' propaganda on national radio stations and in official newspapers.sfnIran Human Rights Documentation Center2007In the late 1970s the Shah's regime consistently lost legitimacy due to criticism that it was pro-Western. As the anti-Shah movement gained ground and support, revolutionary propaganda was spread which alleged that some of the Shah's advisors were Bah's.sfnAbrahamian1982432Bah's were portrayed as economic threats, and as supporters of Israel and the West, and societal hostility against the Bah's increased.sfnIran Human Rights Documentation Center2007sfnSimpsonShubart1995223

Since theIranian RevolutionIslamic Revolutionof 1979 Iranian Bah's have regularly had their homes ransacked or have been banned from attending university or from holding government jobs, and several hundred have received prison sentences for their religious beliefs, most recently for participating inBah' study circlestudy circles.sfnInternational Federation of Human RightsAugust 2003Bah' cemeteries have been desecrated and property has been seized and occasionally demolished, including the House of Mrz Buzurg, Bah'u'llh's father.sfnAffolterJanuary 200575–114The House of the Bb inShiraz, IranShiraz, one of three sites to which Bah's performBah' pilgrimagepilgrimage, has been destroyed twice.sfnAffolterJanuary 200575–114sfnNetherlands Institute of Human Rights8 March 2006sfnBahá'í World News Service2005

According to a US panel, attacks on Bah's in Iran increased underMahmoud Ahmadinejad's presidency.sfnCNN16 May 2008sfnSullivan8 December 2009TheUnited Nations Commission on Human Rightsrevealed an October 2005 confidential letter from Command Headquarters of the Armed Forces of Iran ordering its members to identify Bah's and to monitor their activities. Due to these actions, theSpecial Rapporteur (UN)Special Rapporteurof theUnited Nations Commission on Human Rightsstated on 20 March 2006, that she "also expresses concern that the information gained as a result of such monitoring will be used as a basis for the increased persecution of, and discrimination against, members of the Bah' faith, in violation of international standards. The Special Rapporteur is concerned that this latest development indicates that the situation with regard to religious minorities in Iran is, in fact, deteriorating.sfnJahangir2006

On 14 May 2008, members of an informal body known as the "Friends" that oversaw the needs of the Bah' community in Iran were arrested and taken toEvin prison.sfnCNN16 May 2008sfnIran Human Rights Documentation Center15 May 2008The Friends court case has been postponed several times, but was finally underway on 12 January 2010.sfnCNN12 January 2010Other observers were not allowed in the court. Even the defence lawyers, who for two years have had minimal access to the defendants, had difficulty entering the courtroom. The chairman of the U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom said that it seems that the government has already predetermined the outcome of the case and is violating international human rights law.sfnCNN12 January 2010Further sessions were held on 7 February 2010,sfnWashington TV20 January 201012 April 2010sfnDjavadi8 April 2010and 12 June 2010.sfnRadio Free Europe3 June 2010On 11 August 2010 it became known that the court sentence was 20 years imprisonment for each of the seven prisonerssfnSiegal2010which was later reduced to ten years.sfnCNN16 September 2010After the sentence, they were transferred toGohardasht prison.sfnAFP16 February 2011In March 2011 the sentences were reinstated to the original 20 years.sfnAFP31 March 2011On 3 January 2010, Iranian authorities detained ten more members of the Baha'i minority, reportedly including Leva Khanjani, granddaughter of Jamaloddin Khanjani, one of seven Baha'i leaders jailed since 2008 and in February, they arrested his son, Niki Khanjani.sfnThe Jerusalem Post14 February 2010

The Iranian government claims that the Bah' Faith is not a religion, but is instead a political organization, and hence refuses to recognize it as a minority religion.sfnKravetz1982237However, the government has never produced convincing evidence supporting its characterization of the Bah' community.sfnIran Human Rights Documentation Center20085Also, the government's statements that Bah's who recanted their religion would have their rights restored, attest to the fact that Bah's are persecuted solely for their religious affiliation.sfnIran Human Rights Documentation Center20079The Iranian government also accuses the Bah' Faith of being associated withZionismbecause theBah' World Centreis located in Haifa, Israel.Statement of the Embassy of the Islamic Republic of Iran, Buenos Aires, 26 September 1979, cited inharvnbIran Human Rights Documentation Center2007These accusations against the Bah's have no basis in historical fact,sfnCooper199320sfnSimpsonShubart1995223sfnTavakoli-Targhi2008200and the accusations are used by the Iranian government to use the Bah's as "scapegoats".sfnFreedman26 June 2009In fact it was the Iranian leaderNaser al-Din Shah Qajarwho banished Bah'u'llh fromPersiato theOttoman Empireand Bah'u'llh was later exiled by the OttomanSultan, at the behest of the Persian Shah, to territories further away from Iran and finally toAcre, IsraelAcrein Syria, which only a century later was incorporated into the state ofIsrael.sfnMomen200427-29
article.heading: Egypt
article.paragraph: Bah' institutions and community activities have been illegal under Egyptian law since 1960. All Bah' community properties, including Bah' centers, libraries, and cemeteries, have been confiscated by the government andfatwashave been issued charging Bah's withapostasy.sfnInternational Religious Freedom Report2013[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/religiousfreedom/index.htm?year

TheEgyptian identification card controversybegan in the 1990s when the government modernized the electronic processing ofidentity documents, which introduced a de facto requirement that documents must list the person's religion as Muslim, Christian, or Jewish (the only three religions officially recognized by the government). Consequently, Bah's were unable to obtain government identification documents (such as national identification cards, birth certificates, death certificates, marriage or divorce certificates, or passports) necessary to exercise their rights in their country unless they lied about their religion, which conflicts with Bah' religious principle. Without documents, they could not be employed, educated, treated in hospitals, travel outside of the country, or vote, among other hardships.sfnBigelow16 November 2005Following a protracted legal process culminating in a court ruling favorable to the Bah's, the interior minister of Egypt released a decree on 14 April 2009, amending the law to allow Egyptians who are not Muslim, Christian, or Jewish to obtain identification documents that list dash in place of one of the three recognized religions.sfnBahá'í World News Service17 April 2009The first identification cards were issued to two Bah's under the new decree on 8 August 2009.sfnBahá'í World News Service14 August 2009
